context.text: Such control systems, whose feedback loop is closed via a network, are called Networked Control Systems (NCSs) [1].

The potential of a group to “be more than the sum of its members” has already seeded a variety of recent research directions in system and control community, from modeling of animal groups [1]–[5], to distributed collective covering and searching [6], [7], estimating by groups [8], [9], biologically-motivated optimization [10], [11] and cooperative robotic teams [12], [13].

context.text: The potential of a group to “be more than the sum of its members” has already seeded a variety of recent research directions in system and control community, from modeling of animal groups [1]–[4][5], to distributed collective covering and searching [6], [7], estimating by groups [8], [9], biologically-motivated optimization [10], [11] and cooperative robotic teams [12], [13].

One of the early optimization methods inspired by trail formation in ants was presented in [4], where it was shown that ants that “pursued” one another on \$\mathbb{R}^{2}\$ (each pointing its velocity vector towards a predecessor) had the effect of producing progressively “straighter” trails.
We propose an iterative, decentralized algorithm that involves “local pursuit” (to use the term coined in [4]), of members of a collective, this time in a broader and more intricate setting.

context.text: Spatial discretizations of homeomorphisms are often called topology preserving feature maps [4], [5].
In his classical paper, Kohonen [4] introduced a class of selforganizing adaptive systems that are capable of forming one-or two-dimensional feature maps of the input signal domain.
The convergence properties of Kohonen's self-organizing algorithm have been investigated by several researchers [4], [7], [8], [9], [10].

For the one-dimensional case, Kohonen himself [4] presented a proof of the ordering properties of his algorithm and showed that it converges when the input signal probability distribution, \$f_{U}(u)\$, is uniform.
The feature map's probability does not necessarily have to be equiprobable [4] (unconditional information-theoretic entropy maximization).

We also define the quantizer codebook [6] as the set of \$N\$ output levels and a codebook vector where \$u_{\gamma}\$ is the quantizer output level with the index \$\gamma\$ and the quantizer's feature map [4] \$f(u,\bar{u}):{\rm U}_{{\BBR}}\times {\BBR}^{N}\rightarrow {\bf X}_{{\BBZ}}\$ .
This is often referred to as the feature map \$f(u)\$ in Eq. (5) being equiprobable [4].
By requiring the codebook vector to satisfy Eq. (9), we guarantee that the feature map \$f(u, u^{o})\$ in Eq. (5) is topology preserving [4].

We compare the performance of the integrally distributed learning algorithm presented in this paper against the well-known Kohonen self-organizing learning algorithm [4] to achieve an equiprobable target probability \$p^{o}\$.
A kernel given by Eq. (15) with \$\sigma=2\$ was used in this learning law to update the output weights of neighboring neurons to the winning neuron [4].

However, due to minimizing the duality gap by gradient descent methods, the dynamic equations of such primal-dual networks are usually complicated, even containing high-order nonlinear terms [3] [15].

The disadvantage of dual networks, however, is that they require the inversion of coefficient matrix \$W\$ and thus only able to handle strictly convex quadratic programs preferably with fixed \$W\$ [3].

Moreover, in light of the equivalence of LVI (5) and the ensuing system of piecewise linear equation (also called the linear projection equation), it follows naturally from our neural-network design experience [3] [4] [11]–[16] [22]–[26] that the LVI-based primal-dual neural network solver can be of the following dynamic equation: where \$\gamma>0\$ is the design parameter used to scale the network convergence.

The block diagram on realizing (9) is presented in Fig. 1, where the piecewise-linear activation function \${\cal P}_{\Omega}(\cdot)\$ can be implemented by using operational amplifiers known as limiter [2] [3] [6].

In addition, the LVI-based primal-dual network does not involve matrix inversion, matrix-matrix multiplication or high-order nonlinear computation, thus reducing the implementation and computation complexity, as compared to other recurrent neural models [2] [3] [15] [19].

Note that the existence of the exponential-convergence condition can be justified in practice by considering the equivalence of \$y-{\cal P}_{\Omega}(y-(Hy+p))=0\$ and \$y=y^{\ast}\$, and that it is analyzed in [3] [12] [14] [34] and the references therein.

Based on the dual neural network design experience [3] [11]–[15] [22] [34], we may hope to further simplify the PDNN dynamic equation (9) as the following by removing term \$(I+H^{T}):\dot{y}=\gamma\{{\cal P}_{\Omega}(y-(Hy+p))-y\}\$.

context.text: For example, about the recent research based on recurrent neural networks (specifically, the Hopfield-type neural networks), see [1]–[4] and the references therein.

Motivated by engineering applications of linear/quadratic programming in robotics [4] [11]–[16], however, the following general problem formulation is preferred as the basis of discussion: where \$W\$ is assumed only positive semi-definite such that quadratic programming and linear programming are both to be handled in this formulation.

As the research evolves spirally, a primal-dual neural network model has recently been “discovered” with simple piecewise linear dynamics, global convergence to optimal solutions, and capability of handling QP and LP problems in the same/unified manner [4] [16] [20].

In view of only partial results existing (e.g., in [4] [16] [20], \$q\equiv 0\$ or no inequality constraint \$Ax\leqslant b)\$, this paper presents the whole picture and further study of the LVI-based primal-dual network for solving QP/LP (1)–(4), including rigorous derivation, convergence properties, and solution characteristics.
One fundamental issue in robotics is the inverse kinematics problem [4] [11]–[16] [19]–[22].

Moreover, in light of the equivalence of LVI (5) and the ensuing system of piecewise linear equation (also called the linear projection equation), it follows naturally from our neural-network design experience [3] [4] [11]–[16] [22]–[26] that the LVI-based primal-dual neural network solver can be of the following dynamic equation: where \$\gamma>0\$ is the design parameter used to scale the network convergence.

This numerical result also applies to other neural networks design for robot manipulators and might be the source of the small end-effector positioning error of level \$10^{-4}\sim 10^{-7}\$ m in [4] [11]–[16] [19]–[22] [26] [34].

This numerical result is also applicable to other neural networks design for robot manipulators, and might explain why no divergence of joint variables was observed even in the extreme case (instead, a jump or loss of integration precision may occur) [4] [11]–[16] [19]–[22] [26] [34].

context.text: In this paper, we propose genetic search strategy [9]–[14] as a viable optimal control design technique to incorporate constraints such as fixed-order and strict positive realness of the compensator.
Here we implement genetic algorithms [9]–[14] to find optimal control designs with and without the strict positive real constraint on the compensator.
This feature has been extremely useful in the ease of implementing genetic algorithms for a variety of complex optimization problems [9]–[14].
The algorithms have been used to solve a range of complex problems from combinatorial problems such as the travelling salesman problem [9] to many problems in optimal control [15]–[22].

Specifically, in [12], a partial-state feedback exact model knowledge controller was developed to achieve global exponential link position tracking of a robot manipulator.
Two adaptive, partial-state feedback global asymptotic controllers were also proposed in [12] that compensate for selected uncertainty in the system model.

context.text: The emergence of the neural network paradigm as a powerful tool for learning complex mappings from set of examples has generated a great deal of research in using neural network models for identification and control of dynamical systems with unknown nonlinearities [1]–[3].
In [3], it has been shown that if the linear system derived from the nonlinear model is controllable and observable, the stabilization and regulation problems for nonlinear systems are solvable.

It has been shown in [3] that the asymptotic stability of the zero dynamics together with a well defined relative degree assures the existence of control input that can make the dynamical system follow any arbitrary bounded signal \$y^{m}\$.

context.text: In the case in which both the vector field \$f\$ and the Lyapunov function candidate \$V\$ are polynomial, the Lyapunov conditions are essentially polynomial non-negativity conditions which can be NP hard to test [28] — probably one of the reasons for the lack of algorithmic constructions of Lyapunov functions.

Nevertheless, checking nonnegativity of \$p(x)\$ is an NP-hard problem when the degree of \$p(x)\$ is at least 4 [28], whereas as argued in the previous paragraph, checking whether \$p(x)\$ can be written as an SOS is computationally tractable — it can be formulated as a semidefinite program, which has worst-case polynomial time complexity.

context.text: The sum of squares (SOS) technique was introduced nearly five years ago in Parrilo's thesis [34].
A more detailed description can be found in [34], [36] and the references therein.
See [34]. \$\blacksquare\$.

Since \$p(x)\$ being SOS is equivalent to \$Q\geq 0\$, the problem of finding a \$Q\$ which proves that \$p(x)\$ is an SOS can be cast as a semidefinite program (this was first observed by Parrilo in [34]).
This observation is crucial in the construction of Lyapunov functions and other S-procedure type multipliers [34].
More details can be found in [34].

The observation that the SOS decomposition can be computed efficiently using semidefinite programming [34] has introduced the need for developing software that would facilitate the formulation of the semidefinite programs from their SOS equivalents.
This is the procedure that was originally pursued by Parrilo in his thesis [34].
Other work in this area includes estimation of the domain of attraction [34], [50], LPV analysis and synthesis [58] and nonlinear synthesis [17], [47], [46].

This work represents an extension of the results of [3] that facilitates, through a minor modification of the NS MIMO QFT design methodology, the application of NS MIMO QFT to non-minimum phase (NMP) plant families.
The stability theory developed herein is based on that of [3].

(iii)There are \$2^{n}\$ fuzzy rules in each rule base; that is, there are a total of \$2^{n}\$ input variable combinations of all the possible \$P_{x_{i}}\$ and \$N_{x_{i}}\$ in the IF-part.

context.text: An often-used semiactive control strategy to command a smart damper is clipped optimal control [3]  [5], which employs a linear active control theory to design a primary controller assuming that the structure is linear and the control device is fully active, and a clipping algorithm as a secondary controller to make the damper produce a force close to that commanded by the primary controller (Fig. 1).

context.text: For the non-Lipschitz systems, a recent result [20] developed a feedback domination method to achieve the global output feedback stabilization of (1.1) under a linear growth condition with a constant growth rate.

The homogeneous domination approach that we employ in this paper begins with the linear domination idea proposed in [20] where a global output feedback stabilizer is constructed for uncertain system (1.1) under a linear growth condition.
Inspired by the result [20] obtained by the linear domination approach, we intend to apply the same idea to systems with higher-order nonlinear terms.
Apparently, the linearbased observer and controller in [20] will not have enough control authorities to dominate the higher-order terms such as those in (1.2).

context.text: The primary objective of the approaches presented in [1], [6], [5] and [7] is to design a local decentralized controller for individual agents so that a global objective for the flock can be achieved.
In [1] and [2], authors take double integrator models and design decentralized control laws based on potential functions for both, fixed and dynamic topology of flocks.

In [1], the authors present a class of control laws for fixed topology for a group of double integrator agents such that their velocities converge to the average group velocity, and collisions between the agents are avoided by maintaining the desired separation between all the agents.
We introduce the concept of lookahead to feedback linearize the WMR model in order to obtain it in the double integrator form, and then implement the control law proposed in [1].
We have successfully implemented the coordination algorithm mentioned in [1], in two WMRs and one virtual leader.
In [1], the authors propose a decentralized coordination scheme based on virtual potentials to achieve flocking behavior in a group of multiple agents.

[1],  where, \$k_{1}\$ and \$k_{2}\$ are the gains introduced to avoid saturating the control voltages. \$\alpha_{i}\$ in (21) causes the velocity vectors of all agents to align in the same direction with the same magnitude. \$a_{i}\$, which is a vector in the negative gradient of an artificial potential function \$U_{i}\$, contributes to collision avoidance and cohesion in the group.

The potential \$U_{ij}\$ is a differentiable, nonnegative, radially unbounded function of the distance \$r_{ij}\$ between agents \$i\$ and \$j\$, such that [1]

1)\$U_{ij}(r_{ij})\rightarrow\infty\$ as \$\vert\vert r_{ij}\vert\vert \rightarrow 0\$
2)\$U_{ij}\$ attains its unique minimum when agents \$i\$ and \$j\$ have the desired separation.
We implemented control laws presented in [1] for the double integrator model in WMRs.

context.text: Inspired by this work, numerous research groups have studied the problem of coordinating the motion of multiple autonomous agents for the possible applications in broad areas like automated highways, satellite formation, coordinated movement of a cluster of vehicles for the search and rescue operation [5], and formation flying of unmanned aerial vehicles (DAVs) for the purposes like surveillance and distribution of sensor networks [7].

The primary objective of the approaches presented in [1], [6], [5] and [7] is to design a local decentralized controller for individual agents so that a global objective for the flock can be achieved.

context.text: In the CDMA-2000 IX [1], the inter-frequency hard handoff and quick paging need a frequency synthesizer that has a switching time of \$<500\$ us while keeping the frequency resolution of 10kHz.

However, they need a further improvement of out-of-band phase noise around 1 MHz offset (usually \$>-130{\mathrm dBc}/{\mathrm Hz})\$ for the CDMA-2000 IX PCS application where the out-of-band phase noise should be \$<-135{\mathrm dBc}/{\mathrm Hz}\$ at 1.2 MHz offset, to satisfy the single -tone desensitization requirement [1].

context.text:
The structural design methodology [1]–[4] is based on the following principles:

–every important parameter in a system should be controlled by a feedback loop
–stability in these loops is achieved without compensation by use of the single-stage amplifiers
–system analysis is simplified to the consideration of the gain structure (in a form of signal graph or block diagram)
–system synthesis consists of generation of the set of the gain structure implementations followed by SPICE simulations and selection of the circuit solution based on secondary parameters.

context.text: Recently instrumentation amplifiers using chopper stabilized opamps based on multipath feedforward compensation have been presented that offer noise performance close to the performance of a low noise bipolar opamp and open loop gain in excess of 250db[1], [2].
In the prior art[1], [2] the feedback factor, which is crucial for the stability of the amplifier, is determined by the IC designer.
For example, if there are 3 inputs into a summing node, they will have to be scaled by 1, 2, and 4 to assure robust large signal behavior [1], [2].
To accommodate a wider common mode range, especially Vdd-1.2 v, a different CMFB circuitry than the one used in [1], [2] is used in Il and I3, while replica biasing is used in I5.

context.text: Recently, partially depleted silicon-on-insulator (PD/SOI) has drawn attention as a promising technology for high-performance / low-power deep sub-micron digital integrated circuits [1], [2].
In spite of those advantages of PD/SOI, parasitic bipolar leakage and history dependent delay due to floating body effect can be of serious concern [1], [2].

Parasitic bipolar effect in floating body PD/SOI occurs when source and drain voltages of an NMOS transistor are conditioned “high” and the source (or drain) of the NMOS is subsequently pulled down [1].
Another design issue in the floating body PD/SOI is history dependent delay [1], [2].

context.text: Also, both a 2X over-sampling phase detector and the dual loop DLL were used to generate the optimum sampling clock[5].

In the conventional clock adjusting scheme such as the 2X over-sampling phase tracking scheme[5], the sampling points of extracted clock are sensitive to the time jitter of incoming data due to ISI components.

Although the conventional 2X oversampling method[5] cannot reduce the effect of input jitter, the DFE receiver of this work reduces the effect of input jitter due to ISI and hence the time variation of the sampling clock edge by incorporating the DFE input buffer inside the phase synthesizer DLL loop.

Fig. 4 shows the behavior-level simulation results of the time variation of the sampling clock edge for the conventional 2X over-sampling method[5] and the DFE receiver of this work The time jitter of input data signal due to ISI is assumed to be 270psec.
The time variations of the sampling clock edge at the lock state are 80psec and 280psec for this work and the conventional 2X oversampling method[5], respectively.

context.text: This letter proposes and demonstrates a simple configuration of a multiwavelength laser source based on linear optical amplifiers (LOAs) [8].

A significant difference between LOAs and SOAs is that in LOAs, a vertical-cavity surface-emitting laser is integrated, perpendicularly, along the entire length of the amplifier, serving as a ballast to provide a constant gain to the amplifier [8], helping to clamp the gain competition in a laser cavity.

For this measurement, a pump and a probe technique as reported in [8] and shown in the inset of Fig. 1 was used but the comparison made in this letter was done by operating the two devices at the same value of gain.

The characteristic property of QDs, effective in eliminating pattern effect in the gain-saturated regime (which increases the usable output power), is an ultrafast gain response (\$\sim\$ a few picoseconds) [9], [13]–[18].
Unlike quantum well (QW) and bulk SOAs, this gain response is fast enough to follow the intensity change of 10–40 Gb/s signal and to suppress the gain fluctuation [9], [13]–[18].

Another property of QDs, also contributing to an increase in the usable output power, is the increase in \$P_{\rm sat}\$ by raising the Fermi level at the maximum of current density (limited by the thermal effect) [9], [18], [19], [21].

Another property of QDs, also contributing to an increase in the usable output power, is the increase in \$P_{\rm sat}\$ by raising the Fermi level at the maximum of current density (limited by the thermal effect) [9], [18], [19], [21].

context.text:
Polarization rotation in semiconductor optical amplifiers (SOAs) has found several interesting applications in optical signal processing [1]–
[3], and hence, recently attracted much attention from researchers.
A similar scheme is also used for rectifying the waveform distortion in an SOA caused by gain saturation [1].
The SOA-based power equalizer consists of an input linear polarizer, a polarization-sensitive SOA, polarization controller, and output linear polarizer [1], [2], as shown in Fig. 1(a).

In a polarization-sensitive SOA, the transverse-electric (TE) and transverse-magnetic (TM) components of the input signal experience different gains owing to the TE–TM asymmetry of the confinement factors, effective guide refractive indexes, and carrier distribution of SOA [1].
The output signal is elliptically polarized due to the difference in phase delay of TE–TM components, but it is linearized by the polarization controller after the SOA [1].

context.text: The key problem when using a narrow linewidth optical source to achieve all-optical microwave filtering is the strong environment-dependent optical interference among the time-delayed optical signals because of the high coherence of the narrow linewidth laser source [9]–[11].
However, since all the optical taps travel within the same optical link, environmental perturbations imposed on the different taps are identical; therefore, a stable operation is possible [11].

references.text: Only in nonlinear systems is it meaningful to differentiate small-signal and large-signal instabilities. As we use the terms, small-signal instabilities are those instabilities predicted by equations of motion linearized about a stationary (time-independent, but not necessarily spatially-uniform) solution of the dynamic equations. Under conditions of small-signal instability the amplitude of an arbitrarily small perturbation of the stationary system gradually grows to a limiting amplitude determined by nonlinear saturation mechanisms. Although the limiting signal may be of "large" amplitude, we wish to distinguish these instabilities from the intrinsically large-amplitude instabilities which are characterized by a minimum signal amplitude and which cannot even approximately be described by linearized equations of motion. Systems which are large-signal unstable but small-signal stable will return to a stable time-independent configuration if a disturbing perturbation is less than a critical minimum value. If a perturbation exceeds this critical value, the system will not return to the time-independent configuration but will approach a phase-space trajectory appropriate to cyclic steady-state operation. In systems which are both small-signal and large-signal unstable, it is usually, but not always, true that small-signal instabilities grow to amplitudes characteristic of the large-signal instability.

references.text: Abstract read by title only at the APS meeting in Oak Ridge, TN, March 18,1950. The abstract gave the upper lifetime of 200 but did not publicly reveal a definite comparison with T found in polycrystalline germanium. In the invited paper of [23], I gave 1-5 us to be normal for polycrystalline germanium.

A mobility of 1156 cm2/Vs for electrons in germanium as a measurement of K. Lark-Horovitz and V. A. Johnson in 1946. At the same time they obtained a mobility of 385 cm2/Vs. This information comes from p. 63 of Torrey and Whitmer [11].
This value was obtained by Hall measurements by P. Debye after special purification and by achieving great donor and acceptor uniformity in germanium.
